answers.author: William Follette
answers.text:
We hold a weekly Council Agenda Review/Directors Meeting every Tuesday morning where the City Manager reviews the agenda items for the Thursday morning City Council Study Session.  He steps through each item and asks the appropriate Program Director any questions he might have about the item.  Following that, we review the list of major Agenda presentations for the next six weeks of Council and Council Committee meetings to ensure participants are on schedule.  Following this, we review the next month or two of key community activities from the Community Calendar that our PIO keeps.  Then, we open the floor to any announcements from the Directors such as significant Program/Department events, employee recognition, etc.  This approach has greatly enhanced the level of staff preparedness for Council events and keeps everyone informed about what  other Programs are doing.

answers.author: Barry Crook
answers.text:
In addition to the weekly Agency Head meetings that reviews the upcoming council agenda and worksessions, and a broader department head meeting after the council meeting to relate what happened and what's upcoming (and a "roundtable" where each department relates what is going on, coming up, where they need assistance from anothe department and kudos to other departments for what they have done) we hold a monthly Leadership Team meeting whose purpose is to review our progress against the Council's Top Ten Goals. At that meeting -- in addition to reviewing monthly goals/tasks and scoring them, and outlining the next month's effort -- we have a conversation that reflects on the past month . . . what worked well for the organization -- and why? . . . what didn't go so well -- and why? . . . what can we learn from those two lists . . . the idea is to reflect, learn and apply that learning to continuously improve how we function as an organization. These conversations are often the best ones we have as a leadership group each month.

answers.author: Pamela Muse
answers.text:
Jon - a city I worked for in CA we used to use the non-council meeting week (3 meetings per month) each month at the Department Head meeting we'd featured a department.  For example, after a few minutes of "official business" the host department would provide a full presentation of issues, updates, goals, objectives, special projects, staff updates, etc. for their department.  The next month another department would do their department update review, etc. etc.    
With 11 departments it worked out nicely and we learned a lot about one another and our individual departments – of course, at first we were sure we knew everything about every department.  I really enjoyed the monthly department sponsored meetings.

answers.author: Jessica Roth
answers.text:
Jon - We've been discussing the same issue in Suwanee.  We've always had two staff meetings/month that are very tactical - hearing updates from each department, addressing short-term issues, etc.  After attending some training on High Performance Organizations (Thanks Montgomery, OH!), we've really embraced the idea of spending more effort on leadership development, strategic thinking, etc.  Just this month, we moved forward with changing one of those meetings to a "Q2 Meeting" - this is based on 7 Habits of Highly Effective People, if you haven't read it.  Our first several meetings will be more educational - this month's was on encouraging Q2 throughout our staff team.  In other meetings, we're going to talk about our organizational culture, how to keep employees motivated and engaged, etc.  Once we've gone through this initial educational process as a team, we plan to use these meetings as an opportunity for staff from all levels/departments to strategically plan and address important issues.

answers.author: Richard Blodgett
answers.text:
At the outset create a specific agenda. Someone should keep minutes so you can follow-up on action taken.  The same should carry down to each department, etc.  Employees will agree that if there is no record, nor follow-up, all of our good recommendations are soon forgotten.  This comes from 20 years as a City Manager and 27 years as a consultant to cities and counties.

author: Jon Amundson
text:
We are looking to take our regularly scheduled Executive Team Meetings to the next level. What do you do to make your meetings an effective use of time?
Currently, we hold an 8:30 a.m. Monday morning meeting where we do the following:
Safety Minute
Review Council Agenda
Hot Topics
Adjourn
I know there has got to be a better way. It seems as if we race through the first two items, never come to consensus on Hot Topics and do it all over again next week. 
Sincerely, Tired of Monday Morning Monotony
title: Weekly Executive Team Meetings
